issue.title: Handle `base` in adapters

labels.name: integration
labels.description: Issues related to Astro renderers

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body:
## Changes

- `src/app` now trims the base when looking up routes, so it will match routes when the URL includes the base.
- `src/app` has a new `removeBase` method which trims the base from a pathname. This is useful for adapters that need to look up assets from the filesystem, such as the Node and Deno adapters.
- For the 3 adapters that use this functionality they all have a `major` bump as they now depend on it via the `peerDependency`.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5288

## Testing

Test added in our test adapter which mimics the scenario.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: Astro CLI is slow

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.1

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

N/A

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

macOS

### Describe the Bug

The Astro CLI seems to have a considerable overhead on the functions ran, the best example is the `astro docs` command, on my system it takes around a second to execute while running the original command being wrapped (`open` on macOS) takes only 75ms

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012470-d1233229-75ca-4009-8f5e-ba5676ee05f2.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012506-d4b38236-e9f0-4be2-939a-d04553138fc8.png)

I'm never expecting `astro docs` to be as fast the original command (not exactly a zero cost abstraction), but I do believe we can make it much much faster

Please note that this is not exclusive to the `docs` command, this affects the entire CLI: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199015576-aad4790b-1bf2-4ba3-84bc-ae9850c43ccc.png)

This is most likely related to [all the imports in this file](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/25a6360a60d5029b861725a58541f7fad93ab434/packages/astro/src/cli/index.ts), as removing them manually seems to increase the performance - perhaps some of them could be moved to dynamic imports?

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

any https://astro.new/ project

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

Adds astro cli dynamic imports (#5292)

issue.title: Indentation format exceptions (`.astro`, `.md`)
issue.body:
Continuation of https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5168

As per [.prettierrc.js#L8](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L8):
```js
useTabs: true,
```
And [.prettierrc.js#L20-L23](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L20-L23):
```js
files: ['.*', '*.json', '*.md', '*.toml', '*.yml'],
options: {
  useTabs: false,
},
```
... `.md` files should be indented with spaces, and `.astro` files should be indented with tabs, but currently there are exceptions (roughly 37% of `.astro` files & 11% of `.md` files). I'm happy to open two PRs, one to remove tabs from `.md` files, and one to remove spaces from `.astro` files, thought I should get a thumbs up beforehand to make sure this is wanted.

dot files, `.json` files, `.toml` files, & `.yml` are already as they should be (indented with spaces only, no tabs)
(searched for `^\t` with "files to include" set to `**/.**,.json,.toml,.yml`)

|  | with both | spaces only | tabs only | neither | total |
|--|-----------|-------------|-----------|---------|-------|
| `.astro` 🚀 | 60 (10%) | 161 (27%) | 259 (43%) | 117 (20%) | 597 |
| `.md` ⬇️ | 9 (5%) | 50 (29%) | 11 (6%) | 105 (60%) | 175 |
| `examples` `.astro` 🚀 | 4 (6%) | | 62 (94%) | | 66 |
| `examples` `.md` ⬇️ | 1 (3%) | 5 (13%) | | 32 (84%) | 38 |
| `packages/markdown` (fixtures) `.astro` 🚀 | 1 (3%) | 11 (34%) | 18 (56%) | 2 (6%) | 32 |
| `packages/markdown` `.astro` 🚀 | | | 1 (100%) | | 1 |
| `packages/markdown` `.md` ⬇️ | | 5 (28%) | 4 (22%) | 9 (50%) | 18 |
| `packages/integrations` (fixtures) `.astro` 🚀 | 9 (20%) | 5 (11%) | 25 (54%) | 7 (15%) | 46 |
| `packages/integrations` `.astro` 🚀 | | | 2 (100%) | | 2 |
| `packages/integrations` `.md` ⬇️ | 1 (5%) | 18 (86%) | | 2 (10%) | 21 |
| `packages/astro` `.astro` 🚀 | | | 4 (100%) | | 4 |
| `packages/astro` `.md` ⬇️ | 6 (7%) | 19 (21%) | 6 (7%) | 58 (65%) | 89 |
| `packages/astro` (fixtures) `.astro` 🚀 | 46 (10%) | 145 (33%) | 146 (33%) | 108 (24%) | 445 |
| `packages/astro-prism` `.astro` 🚀 | | | 1 (100%) | | 1 |
| `packages/astro-prism` `.md` ⬇️ | | 1 (100%) | | | 1 |
| `packages/create-astro` `.md` ⬇️ | | | | 1 (100%) | 1 |

(disclaimer: the numbers in the table above are based off of regex searches, I know there are a few case in which e.g. `^ {2}` appears in `.astro` files inside string literals, so take them with a grain of salt)

issue.title: 🐛 BUG: CSS generated by `Astro.glob` is included on all pages

labels.name: styling
labels.description: Discussion and styling related issues

labels.name: p2-has-workaround
labels.description: Bug, but has workaround (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.0.0-beta.63

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

becase `Astro.glob('../pages/posts/*.md')` will render those markdown files it will also include css files used in them. The issue I noticed is that HRM logic will not unload that css files until you restart you `astro dev`.

Steps to reproduce:
1. download `astro-hmr-css-bug` branch from https://github.com/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug
2. run `astro dev`
3. open /posts page
4. now all pages including / and /contacts will have `* {color: red}` css in them
5. restart `astro dev`
6. now your / or /contacts are fine (i.e. not red) until you click on the /posts again

You can do the same with https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug but instead of restarting `astro dev` you would do a full page reload of stackblitz app

Possible solutions:
1. provide `Astro.globMetadataOnly` that will skip markdown rendering 🤪
2. I tested that generally Astro will unload css in less crazy setups, so there's probably some kind of leak in this more indirect case. Compare this to https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-8fswvn?file=src%2Fpages%2Fanother.astro that has `Astro.glob` but if you navigate away from this page css gets properly unloaded

I first saw this issue here: https://youtu.be/EU1MLQMUeXw?t=3490 at 58:58 you can see that I switch to another page but `color: red` is still applied.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Relabelled this as a p2, not because it's not important, it's very important. So important that @bholmesdev has been spending weeks working on a solution for this. Relabelled because p4 is for documented behavior bugs and we do not document that Astro.glob usage will not bleed styles.

issue.title: inconsistent CSS behavior in dynamic routes

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
```yaml
Astro Version:    1.6.1
SSR Adapter:      No
Package Manager:  NPM
Operating System: Windows
Reproduction:     https://github.com/enteleform-codesandbox/0022--Astro--DynamicRoutes-CSS
```

   
When generating routes dynamically, it seems that there are cases where styles from multiple routes are applied at the same time.

After narrowing it down to a minimal repro, the cause seems to be pages having the same HTML output, but different CSS.

This was also the case in the actual project where I initially ran into the issue: a PDF generator that reuses HTML for multiple routes, with changes to the CSS for different print sizes.

It seems like this could potentially be related to #3816. However, this example is using `import.meta.glob`, while the other issue is using `Astro.glob`.
   

-----

## Different HTML
Styles are applied as expected:

![HTML-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847113-60abdac1-bb55-4f61-957f-db8656f1f4da.png)

![CSS-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847110-da2c3fbb-9056-4bd4-bc8a-d8a80cf367cf.png)
   

-----

## Same HTML
Styles from both routes are applied:
![HTML-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847109-74b572e5-b102-419e-86bd-2c8a36719d9a.png)

![CSS-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847112-fa2491e2-2fa5-45cf-b7d8-e0b21aeef755.png)

issue.title: Dep on old language-server leads to multiple versions of the compiler being installed

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.3

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm / yarn

### What operating system are you using?

All

### Describe the Bug

`astro@1.6.3` has a dependency on an older version of the language-server.

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L104

this in turn has a dependency on an older version of prettier-plugin-astro which has a dependency on an older version of `@astrojs/compiler`, which in addition to the direct dependency results in multiple versions of the compiler included in lockfile

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L103

additionally, installing the latest version of the prettier plugin leads to even more duplicate dependencies being installed. this is because `^` on a pre-1.0 package does not include future minor versions.

Potential solutions:
- use peer deps
- use `>=` or `0.X` instead of `^`.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://astro.new/minimal?on=stackblitz

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Does this lead to any actual bugs or just a slower install time?

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

v1.1.6

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Win 11 Enterprise (10.0.22000 Build 22000)

### Describe the Bug

### Tailwind Classes added to HTML-Elements are being ignored or are applied erratically (once Svelte is integrated)

Here are a few things I observed (I used an `H1` with the class `text-*xl` in both, a Svelte component and `.astro` page):

1. When changing `text-*xl` and going up in sizes, it often works for `text-2xl`, `text-3xl` etc. and up to `text-5xl`, then it stops working and jumps back to no styling (even though we now have something like `text-6xl` applied.)
2. Problem seems to be related to the Svelte integration. When Svelte is integrated `.astro` files show an erratic behavior too.
3. Restarting the dev-server "fixes" the problem (e.g classes are applied as they should).
4. When a class was added successfully once (by restarting the dev-server) it seems to work after that. 

Thanks for reading!

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-xtuihr?file=src%2Fpages%2Findex.astro,src%2FTest.svelte&on=stackblitz

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

pull_request.title: Prevent overcaching of astro components for HMR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- The Astro vite plugin compares previous compilation results to determine if an HMR update has resulted in anything more than a style change.
- When doing this, only compare if the module is already in the cache.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/4651

## Testing

- Test case added
- Update the mock file system fallback plugin to account for HMR. This plugin only runs in tests.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

Linux

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body: @GeoffreyBooth There's always a workaround, no doubt. My use-case is not automatic installation of missing dependencies, however. My use-case is allowing a user to install a dependency after they have started a Node.js server without having to kill the process and start it again.

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

comment.body: With that being the case I think we should probably not merge this.

commits.message: Use removeBase in the test adapter

pull_request.title: Handle `base` in adapters
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- `src/app` now trims the base when looking up routes, so it will match routes when the URL includes the base.
- `src/app` has a new `removeBase` method which trims the base from a pathname. This is useful for adapters that need to look up assets from the filesystem, such as the Node and Deno adapters.
- For the 3 adapters that use this functionality they all have a `major` bump as they now depend on it via the `peerDependency`.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5288

## Testing

Test added in our test adapter which mimics the scenario.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: HTMLAttributes Type is missing class:list

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.2

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

The new HTMLAttributes type (#5147) is super helpful but I think it's missing the `class:list` prop. The prop gets omitted in the definition but is actually accessible via
```ts
export type Props = HTMLAttributes<"div">;
const { "class:list": classList } = Astro.props as Props; // Property 'class:list' does not exist on type 'Props'
console.log(classList); // outputs the classes
```
or is this intended?

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-o5vqgz

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
@GeoffreyBooth Aside from that being a very heavy workaround, it doesn't fix the use-case which is *dynamic* requires. Bundlers do not support truly dynamic requires either.

----

@aduh95

> The ESM loader also uses the same packageJsonCache, so clearing it may or may not end up violating the spec in some cases, it's worth exploring but we should remain cautious of unforeseen consequences.

That cache is not exported from this module. Do you mean that it's used indirectly because it somehow uses the CJS loader internally? I'll take your word for it on that then, we can do an explicit `clearRequireCache`.

> I don't share your optimism, it would force a FS lookup for every .js file loaded in a package that doesn't have a package.json, I wouldn't be surprised if it had a very noticeable delay for such packages.

Given that it was added in a PR not related to performance I think this is an edge-case that people have lived with for a long time.

issue.title: Processed script always runs when component is conditionally rendered
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.0

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

Processed scripts always run if a component is included in the template of an Astro page, even if it's excluded by conditional rendering (e.g. `{showThing && <MyComponent />}`). This doesn't affect scripts with `is:inline` applied - they work fine.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-ceknm8?file=src/pages/dont-run.astro

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

issue.title: Processed script always runs when component is conditionally rendered
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.0

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

Processed scripts always run if a component is included in the template of an Astro page, even if it's excluded by conditional rendering (e.g. `{showThing && <MyComponent />}`). This doesn't affect scripts with `is:inline` applied - they work fine.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-ceknm8?file=src/pages/dont-run.astro

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Regular `<script>` are bundled and attached to the head. We wouldn't be able to bundle them if we didn't know if they were going to be used or not. This is a known limitation. `is:inline` is what you should use if you really do want to conditionally render a script.

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
Yes, this is specifically about the CJS cache. Even more specifically the `packageJsonCache` variable added here https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67

Actually I think this bug can be fixed without a new API to clear the cache. @giltayar said:

> Unfortunately, removing this optimization would probably have significant performance disadvantages.

We don't need to remove this optimization, we only need to remove it from caching false-reads. Specifically we just need to remove this line: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/070e111c6578e1e18a29a027d564a958e1a762e2/lib/internal/modules/cjs/loader.js#L337

In this case when a package.json is found it continues to be used from the cache. Only if one is not found would it do another fs read. This seems fine from a performance perspective.

The commit where this was added https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67 was not done for performance reasons, so I'm thinking this is an incidental change.

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

comment.body: @ehuelsmann Sorry for the delay. Can you answer the question about XState? Does it trigger its onchange equivalent for immediate states?

issue.title: Handle `base` in adapters

labels.name: integration
labels.description: Issues related to Astro renderers

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body:
## Changes

- `src/app` now trims the base when looking up routes, so it will match routes when the URL includes the base.
- `src/app` has a new `removeBase` method which trims the base from a pathname. This is useful for adapters that need to look up assets from the filesystem, such as the Node and Deno adapters.
- For the 3 adapters that use this functionality they all have a `major` bump as they now depend on it via the `peerDependency`.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5288

## Testing

Test added in our test adapter which mimics the scenario.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: Astro CLI is slow

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.1

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

N/A

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

macOS

### Describe the Bug

The Astro CLI seems to have a considerable overhead on the functions ran, the best example is the `astro docs` command, on my system it takes around a second to execute while running the original command being wrapped (`open` on macOS) takes only 75ms

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012470-d1233229-75ca-4009-8f5e-ba5676ee05f2.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012506-d4b38236-e9f0-4be2-939a-d04553138fc8.png)

I'm never expecting `astro docs` to be as fast the original command (not exactly a zero cost abstraction), but I do believe we can make it much much faster

Please note that this is not exclusive to the `docs` command, this affects the entire CLI: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199015576-aad4790b-1bf2-4ba3-84bc-ae9850c43ccc.png)

This is most likely related to [all the imports in this file](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/25a6360a60d5029b861725a58541f7fad93ab434/packages/astro/src/cli/index.ts), as removing them manually seems to increase the performance - perhaps some of them could be moved to dynamic imports?

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

any https://astro.new/ project

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

These changes make the cli ~50% faster.

## Testing

Tested with ```pnpm run test:match "cli"```

## Docs

No docs need to be updated, only internal behaviour has been changed.

issue.title: Indentation format exceptions (`.astro`, `.md`)
issue.body:
Continuation of https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5168

As per [.prettierrc.js#L8](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L8):
```js
useTabs: true,
```
And [.prettierrc.js#L20-L23](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L20-L23):
```js
files: ['.*', '*.json', '*.md', '*.toml', '*.yml'],
options: {
  useTabs: false,
},
```

issue.title: 🐛 BUG: CSS generated by `Astro.glob` is included on all pages

labels.name: styling
labels.description: Discussion and styling related issues

labels.name: p2-has-workaround
labels.description: Bug, but has workaround (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.0.0-beta.63

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

becase `Astro.glob('../pages/posts/*.md')` will render those markdown files it will also include css files used in them. The issue I noticed is that HRM logic will not unload that css files until you restart you `astro dev`.

Steps to reproduce:
1. download `astro-hmr-css-bug` branch from https://github.com/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug
2. run `astro dev`
3. open /posts page
4. now all pages including / and /contacts will have `* {color: red}` css in them
5. restart `astro dev`
6. now your / or /contacts are fine (i.e. not red) until you click on the /posts again

You can do the same with https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug but instead of restarting `astro dev` you would do a full page reload of stackblitz app

Possible solutions:
1. provide `Astro.globMetadataOnly` that will skip markdown rendering 🤪
2. I tested that generally Astro will unload css in less crazy setups, so there's probably some kind of leak in this more indirect case. Compare this to https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-8fswvn?file=src%2Fpages%2Fanother.astro that has `Astro.glob` but if you navigate away from this page css gets properly unloaded

I first saw this issue here: https://youtu.be/EU1MLQMUeXw?t=3490 at 58:58 you can see that I switch to another page but `color: red` is still applied.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Relabelled this as a p2, not because it's not important, it's very important. So important that @bholmesdev has been spending weeks working on a solution for this. Relabelled because p4 is for documented behavior bugs and we do not document that Astro.glob usage will not bleed styles.

issue.title: inconsistent CSS behavior in dynamic routes

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
```yaml
Astro Version:    1.6.1
SSR Adapter:      No
Package Manager:  NPM
Operating System: Windows
Reproduction:     https://github.com/enteleform-codesandbox/0022--Astro--DynamicRoutes-CSS
```

   
When generating routes dynamically, it seems that there are cases where styles from multiple routes are applied at the same time.

After narrowing it down to a minimal repro, the cause seems to be pages having the same HTML output, but different CSS.

This was also the case in the actual project where I initially ran into the issue: a PDF generator that reuses HTML for multiple routes, with changes to the CSS for different print sizes.

It seems like this could potentially be related to #3816. However, this example is using `import.meta.glob`, while the other issue is using `Astro.glob`.
   

-----

## Different HTML
Styles are applied as expected:

![HTML-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847113-60abdac1-bb55-4f61-957f-db8656f1f4da.png)

![CSS-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847110-da2c3fbb-9056-4bd4-bc8a-d8a80cf367cf.png)
   

-----

## Same HTML
Styles from both routes are applied:
![HTML-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847109-74b572e5-b102-419e-86bd-2c8a36719d9a.png)

![CSS-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847112-fa2491e2-2fa5-45cf-b7d8-e0b21aeef755.png)

issue.title: Dep on old language-server leads to multiple versions of the compiler being installed

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.3

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm / yarn

### What operating system are you using?

All

### Describe the Bug

`astro@1.6.3` has a dependency on an older version of the language-server.

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L104

this in turn has a dependency on an older version of prettier-plugin-astro which has a dependency on an older version of `@astrojs/compiler`, which in addition to the direct dependency results in multiple versions of the compiler included in lockfile

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L103

additionally, installing the latest version of the prettier plugin leads to even more duplicate dependencies being installed. this is because `^` on a pre-1.0 package does not include future minor versions.

Potential solutions:
- use peer deps
- use `>=` or `0.X` instead of `^`.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://astro.new/minimal?on=stackblitz

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

issue.title: BUG: TailwindCSS + Svelte: Hot Reload shows erratic behavior

labels.name: styling
labels.description: Discussion and styling related issues

labels.name: framework-svelte
labels.description: Issues related to Svelte

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

v1.1.6

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Win 11 Enterprise (10.0.22000 Build 22000)

### Describe the Bug

### Tailwind Classes added to HTML-Elements are being ignored or are applied erratically (once Svelte is integrated)

Here are a few things I observed (I used an `H1` with the class `text-*xl` in both, a Svelte component and `.astro` page):

1. When changing `text-*xl` and going up in sizes, it often works for `text-2xl`, `text-3xl` etc. and up to `text-5xl`, then it stops working and jumps back to no styling (even though we now have something like `text-6xl` applied.)
2. Problem seems to be related to the Svelte integration. When Svelte is integrated `.astro` files show an erratic behavior too.
3. Restarting the dev-server "fixes" the problem (e.g classes are applied as they should).
4. When a class was added successfully once (by restarting the dev-server) it seems to work after that. 

Thanks for reading!

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-xtuihr?file=src%2Fpages%2Findex.astro,src%2FTest.svelte&on=stackblitz

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

pull_request.title: Prevent overcaching of astro components for HMR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- The Astro vite plugin compares previous compilation results to determine if an HMR update has resulted in anything more than a style change.
- When doing this, only compare if the module is already in the cache.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/4651

## Testing

- Test case added
- Update the mock file system fallback plugin to account for HMR. This plugin only runs in tests.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

comment.body: With that being the case I think we should probably not merge this.

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
@GeoffreyBooth Aside from that being a very heavy workaround, it doesn't fix the use-case which is *dynamic* requires. Bundlers do not support truly dynamic requires either.

----

@aduh95

> The ESM loader also uses the same packageJsonCache, so clearing it may or may not end up violating the spec in some cases, it's worth exploring but we should remain cautious of unforeseen consequences.

That cache is not exported from this module. Do you mean that it's used indirectly because it somehow uses the CJS loader internally? I'll take your word for it on that then, we can do an explicit `clearRequireCache`.

> I don't share your optimism, it would force a FS lookup for every .js file loaded in a package that doesn't have a package.json, I wouldn't be surprised if it had a very noticeable delay for such packages.

Given that it was added in a PR not related to performance I think this is an edge-case that people have lived with for a long time.

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

Processed scripts always run if a component is included in the template of an Astro page, even if it's excluded by conditional rendering (e.g. `{showThing && <MyComponent />}`). This doesn't affect scripts with `is:inline` applied - they work fine.

comment.body: Regular `<script>` are bundled and attached to the head. We wouldn't be able to bundle them if we didn't know if they were going to be used or not. This is a known limitation. `is:inline` is what you should use if you really do want to conditionally render a script.

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
Yes, this is specifically about the CJS cache. Even more specifically the `packageJsonCache` variable added here https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67

Actually I think this bug can be fixed without a new API to clear the cache. @giltayar said:

> Unfortunately, removing this optimization would probably have significant performance disadvantages.

We don't need to remove this optimization, we only need to remove it from caching false-reads. Specifically we just need to remove this line: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/070e111c6578e1e18a29a027d564a958e1a762e2/lib/internal/modules/cjs/loader.js#L337

In this case when a package.json is found it continues to be used from the cache. Only if one is not found would it do another fs read. This seems fine from a performance perspective.

The commit where this was added https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67 was not done for performance reasons, so I'm thinking this is an incidental change.

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

issue.title: Handle `base` in adapters

labels.name: integration
labels.description: Issues related to Astro renderers

labels.name: core
labels.description: PRs that modify the core `astro` package.

issue.body:
## Changes

- `src/app` now trims the base when looking up routes, so it will match routes when the URL includes the base.
- `src/app` has a new `removeBase` method which trims the base from a pathname. This is useful for adapters that need to look up assets from the filesystem, such as the Node and Deno adapters.
- For the 3 adapters that use this functionality they all have a `major` bump as they now depend on it via the `peerDependency`.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5288

## Testing

Test added in our test adapter which mimics the scenario.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

issue.title: Astro CLI is slow

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.1

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

N/A

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

macOS

### Describe the Bug

The Astro CLI seems to have a considerable overhead on the functions ran, the best example is the `astro docs` command, on my system it takes around a second to execute while running the original command being wrapped (`open` on macOS) takes only 75ms

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012470-d1233229-75ca-4009-8f5e-ba5676ee05f2.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199012506-d4b38236-e9f0-4be2-939a-d04553138fc8.png)

I'm never expecting `astro docs` to be as fast the original command (not exactly a zero cost abstraction), but I do believe we can make it much much faster

Please note that this is not exclusive to the `docs` command, this affects the entire CLI: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3019731/199015576-aad4790b-1bf2-4ba3-84bc-ae9850c43ccc.png)

This is most likely related to [all the imports in this file](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/25a6360a60d5029b861725a58541f7fad93ab434/packages/astro/src/cli/index.ts), as removing them manually seems to increase the performance - perhaps some of them could be moved to dynamic imports?

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

any https://astro.new/ project

### Participation

- [X] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

issue.title: Indentation format exceptions (`.astro`, `.md`)
issue.body:
Continuation of https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5168

As per [.prettierrc.js#L8](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L8):
```js
useTabs: true,
```
And [.prettierrc.js#L20-L23](https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/bf5ad72/.prettierrc.js#L20-L23):
```js
files: ['.*', '*.json', '*.md', '*.toml', '*.yml'],
options: {
  useTabs: false,
},
```
... `.md` files should be indented with spaces, and `.astro` files should be indented with tabs, but currently there are exceptions (roughly 37% of `.astro` files & 11% of `.md` files). I'm happy to open two PRs, one to remove tabs from `.md` files, and one to remove spaces from `.astro` files, thought I should get a thumbs up beforehand to make sure this is wanted.

dot files, `.json` files, `.toml` files, & `.yml` are already as they should be (indented with spaces only, no tabs)
(searched for `^\t` with "files to include" set to `**/.**,.json,.toml,.yml`)

|  | with both | spaces only | tabs only | neither | total |

issue.title: 🐛 BUG: CSS generated by `Astro.glob` is included on all pages

labels.name: styling
labels.description: Discussion and styling related issues

labels.name: p2-has-workaround
labels.description: Bug, but has workaround (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.0.0-beta.63

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

pnpm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

becase `Astro.glob('../pages/posts/*.md')` will render those markdown files it will also include css files used in them. The issue I noticed is that HRM logic will not unload that css files until you restart you `astro dev`.

Steps to reproduce:
1. download `astro-hmr-css-bug` branch from https://github.com/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug
2. run `astro dev`
3. open /posts page
4. now all pages including / and /contacts will have `* {color: red}` css in them
5. restart `astro dev`
6. now your / or /contacts are fine (i.e. not red) until you click on the /posts again

You can do the same with https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug but instead of restarting `astro dev` you would do a full page reload of stackblitz app

Possible solutions:
1. provide `Astro.globMetadataOnly` that will skip markdown rendering 🤪
2. I tested that generally Astro will unload css in less crazy setups, so there's probably some kind of leak in this more indirect case. Compare this to https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-8fswvn?file=src%2Fpages%2Fanother.astro that has `Astro.glob` but if you navigate away from this page css gets properly unloaded

I first saw this issue here: https://youtu.be/EU1MLQMUeXw?t=3490 at 58:58 you can see that I switch to another page but `color: red` is still applied.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/github/JLarky/jlarky-blog/tree/astro-hmr-css-bug

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Relabelled this as a p2, not because it's not important, it's very important. So important that @bholmesdev has been spending weeks working on a solution for this. Relabelled because p4 is for documented behavior bugs and we do not document that Astro.glob usage will not bleed styles.

issue.title: inconsistent CSS behavior in dynamic routes

labels.name: p4-important
labels.description: Violate documented behavior or significantly improves performance (priority)

issue.body:
```yaml
Astro Version:    1.6.1
SSR Adapter:      No
Package Manager:  NPM
Operating System: Windows
Reproduction:     https://github.com/enteleform-codesandbox/0022--Astro--DynamicRoutes-CSS
```

   
When generating routes dynamically, it seems that there are cases where styles from multiple routes are applied at the same time.

After narrowing it down to a minimal repro, the cause seems to be pages having the same HTML output, but different CSS.

This was also the case in the actual project where I initially ran into the issue: a PDF generator that reuses HTML for multiple routes, with changes to the CSS for different print sizes.

It seems like this could potentially be related to #3816. However, this example is using `import.meta.glob`, while the other issue is using `Astro.glob`.
   

-----

## Different HTML
Styles are applied as expected:

![HTML-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847113-60abdac1-bb55-4f61-957f-db8656f1f4da.png)

![CSS-Different](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847110-da2c3fbb-9056-4bd4-bc8a-d8a80cf367cf.png)
   

-----

## Same HTML
Styles from both routes are applied:
![HTML-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847109-74b572e5-b102-419e-86bd-2c8a36719d9a.png)

![CSS-Same](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10906415/198847112-fa2491e2-2fa5-45cf-b7d8-e0b21aeef755.png)

issue.title: Dep on old language-server leads to multiple versions of the compiler being installed

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.3

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm / yarn

### What operating system are you using?

All

### Describe the Bug

`astro@1.6.3` has a dependency on an older version of the language-server.

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L104

this in turn has a dependency on an older version of prettier-plugin-astro which has a dependency on an older version of `@astrojs/compiler`, which in addition to the direct dependency results in multiple versions of the compiler included in lockfile

https://github.com/withastro/astro/blob/89f335b5399bf9511baa08841086c7afb05d8208/packages/astro/package.json#L103

additionally, installing the latest version of the prettier plugin leads to even more duplicate dependencies being installed. this is because `^` on a pre-1.0 package does not include future minor versions.

Potential solutions:
- use peer deps
- use `>=` or `0.X` instead of `^`.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://astro.new/minimal?on=stackblitz

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

v1.1.6

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Win 11 Enterprise (10.0.22000 Build 22000)

### Describe the Bug

### Tailwind Classes added to HTML-Elements are being ignored or are applied erratically (once Svelte is integrated)

Here are a few things I observed (I used an `H1` with the class `text-*xl` in both, a Svelte component and `.astro` page):

1. When changing `text-*xl` and going up in sizes, it often works for `text-2xl`, `text-3xl` etc. and up to `text-5xl`, then it stops working and jumps back to no styling (even though we now have something like `text-6xl` applied.)
2. Problem seems to be related to the Svelte integration. When Svelte is integrated `.astro` files show an erratic behavior too.
3. Restarting the dev-server "fixes" the problem (e.g classes are applied as they should).
4. When a class was added successfully once (by restarting the dev-server) it seems to work after that. 

Thanks for reading!

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-xtuihr?file=src%2Fpages%2Findex.astro,src%2FTest.svelte&on=stackblitz

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

pull_request.title: Prevent overcaching of astro components for HMR
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- The Astro vite plugin compares previous compilation results to determine if an HMR update has resulted in anything more than a style change.
- When doing this, only compare if the module is already in the cache.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/4651

## Testing

- Test case added
- Update the mock file system fallback plugin to account for HMR. This plugin only runs in tests.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

_No response_

_No response_

On the second require the module is loaded

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body: @GeoffreyBooth There's always a workaround, no doubt. My use-case is not automatic installation of missing dependencies, however. My use-case is allowing a user to install a dependency after they have started a Node.js server without having to kill the process and start it again.

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

comment.body: With that being the case I think we should probably not merge this.

commits.message: Use removeBase in the test adapter

pull_request.title: Handle `base` in adapters
pull_request.body:
## Changes

- `src/app` now trims the base when looking up routes, so it will match routes when the URL includes the base.
- `src/app` has a new `removeBase` method which trims the base from a pathname. This is useful for adapters that need to look up assets from the filesystem, such as the Node and Deno adapters.
- For the 3 adapters that use this functionality they all have a `major` bump as they now depend on it via the `peerDependency`.
- Fixes https://github.com/withastro/astro/issues/5288

## Testing

Test added in our test adapter which mimics the scenario.

## Docs

N/A, bug fix

If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.


# Releases

-   [#5198](https://github.com/withastro/astro/pull/5198) [`c77a6cbe3`](https://github.com/withastro/astro/commit/c77a6cbe345facbf72c453e2fddc00f20c98983f) Thanks [@matthewp](https://github.com/matthewp)! - HMR - Improved error recovery

    This improves error recovery for HMR. Now when the dev server finds itself in an error state (because a route contained an error), it will recover from that state and refresh the page when the user has corrected the mistake.

issue.title: HTMLAttributes Type is missing class:list

labels.name: p2-nice-to-have
labels.description: Not breaking anything but nice to have (priority)

issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.2

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

The new HTMLAttributes type (#5147) is super helpful but I think it's missing the `class:list` prop. The prop gets omitted in the definition but is actually accessible via
```ts
export type Props = HTMLAttributes<"div">;
const { "class:list": classList } = Astro.props as Props; // Property 'class:list' does not exist on type 'Props'
console.log(classList); // outputs the classes
```
or is this intended?

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
@GeoffreyBooth Aside from that being a very heavy workaround, it doesn't fix the use-case which is *dynamic* requires. Bundlers do not support truly dynamic requires either.

----

@aduh95

> The ESM loader also uses the same packageJsonCache, so clearing it may or may not end up violating the spec in some cases, it's worth exploring but we should remain cautious of unforeseen consequences.

That cache is not exported from this module. Do you mean that it's used indirectly because it somehow uses the CJS loader internally? I'll take your word for it on that then, we can do an explicit `clearRequireCache`.

> I don't share your optimism, it would force a FS lookup for every .js file loaded in a package that doesn't have a package.json, I wouldn't be surprised if it had a very noticeable delay for such packages.

Given that it was added in a PR not related to performance I think this is an edge-case that people have lived with for a long time.

issue.title: Processed script always runs when component is conditionally rendered
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.0

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

Processed scripts always run if a component is included in the template of an Astro page, even if it's excluded by conditional rendering (e.g. `{showThing && <MyComponent />}`). This doesn't affect scripts with `is:inline` applied - they work fine.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-ceknm8?file=src/pages/dont-run.astro

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

issue.title: Processed script always runs when component is conditionally rendered
issue.body:
### What version of `astro` are you using?

1.6.0

### Are you using an SSR adapter? If so, which one?

None

### What package manager are you using?

npm

### What operating system are you using?

Mac

### Describe the Bug

Processed scripts always run if a component is included in the template of an Astro page, even if it's excluded by conditional rendering (e.g. `{showThing && <MyComponent />}`). This doesn't affect scripts with `is:inline` applied - they work fine.

### Link to Minimal Reproducible Example

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-ceknm8?file=src/pages/dont-run.astro

### Participation

- [ ] I am willing to submit a pull request for this issue.

comment.body: Regular `<script>` are bundled and attached to the head. We wouldn't be able to bundle them if we didn't know if they were going to be used or not. This is a known limitation. `is:inline` is what you should use if you really do want to conditionally render a script.

issue.title: Requiring a dynamically added dependency fails when the package has no `index.js` file

labels.name: module
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the module subsystem.

labels.name: esm
labels.description: Issues and PRs related to the ECMAScript Modules implementation.

issue.body:
### Version

v7.1.0 and newer (last working version was v6.17.1)

### Platform

Linux

### Subsystem

_No response_

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

Require a dependency that doesn't exist. Catch the error. Dynamically add the missing package to the node_modules. It should not contain an `index.js` file but should use a custom entry point instead. Require the now not missing package again.

Expected result: the modules is loaded.
Actual result: module not found error is thrown.

I have create a repro repo: https://github.com/zkochan/require-issue


### How often does it reproduce? Is there a required condition?

_No response_

### What is the expected behavior?

_No response_

### What do you see instead?

On the second require the module is loaded

### Additional information

cc @GiladShoham @davidfirst

comment.body:
Yes, this is specifically about the CJS cache. Even more specifically the `packageJsonCache` variable added here https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67

Actually I think this bug can be fixed without a new API to clear the cache. @giltayar said:

> Unfortunately, removing this optimization would probably have significant performance disadvantages.

We don't need to remove this optimization, we only need to remove it from caching false-reads. Specifically we just need to remove this line: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/070e111c6578e1e18a29a027d564a958e1a762e2/lib/internal/modules/cjs/loader.js#L337

In this case when a package.json is found it continues to be used from the cache. Only if one is not found would it do another fs read. This seems fine from a performance perspective.

The commit where this was added https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/4396bebfe1fc024ff6badf2ead40f1b5127d4e67 was not done for performance reasons, so I'm thinking this is an incidental change.

issue.title: Issue 179: `onChange` not called for `immediate` states
issue.body:
This PR solves issue #179; it makes sure `onChange()` is called for every state the machine transitions to.

There is an additional side effect to this change: it doesn't call `onChange()` when `send()` is called with an unsupported event name. That is, if a state only has a transition triggering on the "done" event, `onChange()` would be called even when executing `send("fail")`. This commit does *not* eliminate the case where the machine transitions from and to one and the same state, although with this change, detecting that situation and eliminating the invocations should be trivial.

comment.body: @ehuelsmann Sorry for the delay. Can you answer the question about XState? Does it trigger its onchange equivalent for immediate states?
